**Helsinki** ^[\[a\]](#cite_note-10)^^[\[b\]](#cite_note-11)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and most populous [city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Finland "List of cities and towns in Finland") in [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland"). It is on the shore of the [Gulf of Finland](/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland "Gulf of Finland") and is the seat of southern Finland's [Uusimaa](/wiki/Uusimaa "Uusimaa") region. About 685,000 people live in the municipality, with 1.3 million in the [capital region](/wiki/Helsinki_capital_region "Helsinki capital region") and 1.61 million in the [metropolitan area](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area"). As the most populous [urban area](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_Finland_by_population "List of urban areas in Finland by population") in Finland, it is the country's most significant centre for politics, education, finance, culture, and research. Helsinki is 80 kilometres (50 mi) north of [Tallinn, Estonia](/wiki/Tallinn,_Estonia "Tallinn, Estonia"), 400 kilometres (250 mi) east of [Stockholm, Sweden](/wiki/Stockholm,_Sweden "Stockholm, Sweden"), and 300 kilometres (190 mi) west of [Saint Petersburg, Russia](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg,_Russia "Saint Petersburg, Russia"). Helsinki has significant [historical connections](/wiki/History_of_Helsinki "History of Helsinki") with these three cities.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-11}

Together with the cities of [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo"), [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa") and [Kauniainen](/wiki/Kauniainen "Kauniainen")---and surrounding commuter towns,^[\[10\]](#cite_note-12)^ including the neighbouring municipality of [Sipoo](/wiki/Sipoo "Sipoo") to the east^[\[11\]](#cite_note-13)^---Helsinki forms a [metropolitan area](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area"). This area is often considered Finland's only metropolis and is the world's [northernmost](/wiki/List_of_northernmost_items#Cities_and_settlements "List of northernmost items") metropolitan area with over one million inhabitants. Additionally, it is the northernmost capital of an [EU member state](/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union "Member state of the European Union"). Helsinki is the [third-largest](/wiki/List_of_the_most_populated_municipalities_in_the_Nordic_countries "List of the most populated municipalities in the Nordic countries") municipality in the Nordic countries, after Stockholm and [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo "Oslo"). Its urban area is the [third-largest](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_Nordic_countries "List of urban areas in the Nordic countries") in the Nordic countries, after Stockholm and [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"). [Helsinki Airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport"), in the neighbouring city of Vantaa, serves the city with frequent flights to numerous destinations in Europe, North America, and Asia.{#cite_ref-13}

Helsinki is a [bilingual](/wiki/Bilingual "Bilingual") municipality with [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language") and [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language") as its official languages. The population consists of 75% Finnish speakers, 5% Swedish speakers, and 20% speakers of other languages (which is well above the national average).

Helsinki hosted the [1952 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics"), the first [CSCE](/wiki/Conference_on_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe")/[OSCE](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") Summit in 1975, the first [World Athletics Championships](/wiki/World_Athletics_Championships "World Athletics Championships") in 1983, the [52nd Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2007 "Eurovision Song Contest 2007") in 2007 and it was the 2012 [World Design Capital](/wiki/World_Design_Capital "World Design Capital").^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Worlddesigncapital.com-14)^{#cite_ref-Worlddesigncapital.com_14-0}

Helsinki has one of the highest standards of urban living in the world. In 2011, the British magazine *[Monocle](/wiki/Monocle_(UK_magazine) "Monocle (UK magazine)")* ranked Helsinki as the world's most liveable city in its [livable cities index](/wiki/City_quality_of_life_indices "City quality of life indices").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-15)^ In the [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit")'s 2016 livability survey, Helsinki ranked ninth out of 140 cities.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-2016_detail-16)^ In July 2021, the American magazine *[Time](/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")* named Helsinki one of the world's greatest places, a city that "can grow into a burgeoning cultural nest in the future" and is already known as an [environmental](/wiki/Natural_environment "Natural environment") pioneer.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-17)^ In an international *Cities of Choice* survey conducted in 2021 by the [Boston Consulting Group](/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group "Boston Consulting Group") and the BCG Henderson Institute, Helsinki was ranked the third-best city in the world to live in, with [London](/wiki/London "London") and [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") coming in first and second.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-18)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-19)^ In the *[Condé Nast Traveler](/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Traveler "Condé Nast Traveler")* magazine's 2023 Readers' Choice Awards, Helsinki was ranked the 4th-friendliest city in Europe.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-20)^ Helsinki, along with [Rovaniemi](/wiki/Rovaniemi "Rovaniemi") in [Lapland](/wiki/Lapland_(Finland) "Lapland (Finland)"), is also one of Finland's most important [tourist](/wiki/Tourism "Tourism") cities.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-21)^ Due to the large number of sea passengers, Helsinki is classified as a major port city,^[\[20\]](#cite_note-22)^ and in 2017 it was rated the world's busiest passenger port.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

According to a theory put forward in the 1630s, at the time of [Swedish colonisation](/wiki/Swedish_colonisation_of_Finland "Swedish colonisation of Finland") of the Finnish coast, colonists from [Hälsingland](/wiki/H%C3%A4lsingland "Hälsingland") in central [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") arrived at what is now the [Vantaa River](/wiki/Vantaa_(river) "Vantaa (river)") and called it *Helsingå* ('Helsinge River'), giving rise to the names of the [village](/wiki/Helsingin_pit%C3%A4j%C3%A4n_kirkonkyl%C3%A4 "Helsingin pitäjän kirkonkylä") and [church](/wiki/Church_of_St._Lawrence,_Vantaa "Church of St. Lawrence, Vantaa") of Helsinge in the 1300s.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-24)^ This theory is questionable, as dialect research suggests that the settlers came from [Uppland](/wiki/Uppland "Uppland") and the surrounding areas.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-25)^ Others have suggested that the name derives from the Swedish word *helsing*, an archaic form of the word *hals* ('[neck](/wiki/Neck "Neck")'), which refers to the narrowest part of a river, the [rapids](/wiki/Rapids "Rapids").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-26)^ Other Scandinavian towns in similar geographical locations were given similar names at the time, such as [Helsingør](/wiki/Helsing%C3%B8r "Helsingør") in Denmark and [Helsingborg](/wiki/Helsingborg "Helsingborg") in Sweden.{#cite_ref-26}

When a town was founded in the village of [Forsby](/wiki/Koskela "Koskela") (later *Koskela*) in 1548, it was called *Helsinge fors*, 'Helsinge rapids'. The name refers to the [Vanhankaupunginkoski](/w/index.php?title=Vanhankaupunginkoski&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vanhankaupunginkoski (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanhankaupunginkoski "fi:Vanhankaupunginkoski")\] rapids at the mouth of the river.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-27)^ The town was commonly known as *Helsinge* or *Helsing*, from which the modern Finnish name is derived.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-28)^{#cite_ref-28}

Official [Finnish government](/wiki/Council_of_State_(Finland) "Council of State (Finland)") documents and Finnish language newspapers have used the name *Helsinki* since 1819, when the [Senate of Finland](/wiki/Senate_of_Finland "Senate of Finland") moved to the city from [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku"), the former capital of Finland. Decrees issued in Helsinki were dated with Helsinki as the place of issue. This is how the form Helsinki came to be used in [written](/wiki/Literary_language "Literary language") Finnish.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-29)^ When Finland became a Grand Duchy of Finland, an autonomous state under the rule of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), Helsinki was known as *Gel'singfors* (Гельсингфорс) in Russian, because the main and official language of Grand Duchy of Finland was Swedish.{#cite_ref-29}

In [Helsinki slang](/wiki/Helsinki_slang "Helsinki slang"), the city is called *Stadi* (from the Swedish word *stad*, meaning 'city'). Abbreviated form *Hesa* is equally common, but its use is associated with people of rural origin ("junantuomat", lit. "brought by a train") and frowned upon by locals.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-nickname-1)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-30)^ *Helsset* is the [Northern Sami](/wiki/Northern_Sami "Northern Sami") name for Helsinki.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-samigrammar-31)^{#cite_ref-samigrammar_31-0}

### Early history {#Early_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early history")\]

After the end of the [Ice Age](/wiki/Last_Glacial_Period "Last Glacial Period") and the retreat of the ice sheet, the first settlers arrived in the Helsinki area around 5000 BC. Their presence has been documented by archaeologists in [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa"), [Pitäjänmäki](/wiki/Pit%C3%A4j%C3%A4nm%C3%A4ki "Pitäjänmäki") and [Kaarela](/wiki/Kaarela "Kaarela").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-NKent-32)^ Permanent settlements did not appear until the beginning of the 1st millennium AD, during the [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age"), when the area was inhabited by the [Tavastians](/wiki/Tavastians "Tavastians"). They used the area for fishing and hunting, but due to the lack of archaeological finds it is difficult to say how extensive their settlements were. [Pollen analysis](/wiki/Palynology "Palynology") has shown that there were agricultural settlements in the area in the 10th century, and surviving historical records from the 14th century describe Tavastian settlements in the area.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-:0-33)^{#cite_ref-:0_33-0}

[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") does not gain a significant foothold in Finland before the 11th century. After that, a number of [crosses](/wiki/Christian_cross "Christian cross") and other objects related to Christianity can be found in archaeological material. According to the traditional view, the [Kingdom of Sweden](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sweden_(800%E2%80%931521) "Kingdom of Sweden (800–1521)") made three crusades to Finland, thanks to which the region was incorporated into both Christianity and the Swedish Empire. Recent research has shown that these expeditions, to the extent that there were even three of them, were not the crusades that had been imagined. Later, the conquest of Finland was justified in terms of "civilisation" and "christianisation", and the myth of the Crusades was developed. It is more likely that it was a multidimensional combination of economic, cultural and political power ambitions.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}

The early settlements were raided by [Vikings](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings") until 1008, and the [Battle at Herdaler](/wiki/Battle_at_Herdaler "Battle at Herdaler") was a battle between the Norse Viking leader Olav Haraldsson (later King [Olaf II of Norway](/wiki/Olaf_II_of_Norway "Olaf II of Norway"), also known as Saint Olaf) and local Finns at Herdaler (now [Ingå](/wiki/Ing%C3%A5 "Ingå")), not far from Helsinga, around 1007--8.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-35)^ The [Saga of Olaf Haraldson](/wiki/Heimskringla "Heimskringla") tells how Olav raided the coasts of Finland and was almost killed in battle. He ran away in fear and after that the Vikings did not raid the coasts of Finland.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-36)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-37)^{#cite_ref-37}

Later the area was settled by Christians from Sweden. They came mainly from the Swedish coastal regions of [Norrland](/wiki/Norrland "Norrland") and [Hälsingland](/wiki/H%C3%A4lsingland "Hälsingland"), and their migration intensified around 1100.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-NKent-32)^ The [Swedes permanently colonised](/wiki/Swedish_colonisation_of_Finland "Swedish colonisation of Finland") the Helsinki region's coastline in the late 13th century, after the successful crusade to Finland that led to the defeat of the Tavastians.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-38)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-:0-33)^{#cite_ref-:0_33-1}

In the Middle Ages, the Helsinki area was a landscape of small villages. Some of the old villages from the 1240s in the area of present-day Helsinki, such as [Koskela](/wiki/Koskela "Koskela") and [Töölö](/wiki/T%C3%B6%C3%B6l%C3%B6 "Töölö"), are now Helsinki districts, as are the rest of the 27 medieval villages. The area gradually became part of the Kingdom of Sweden and Christianity. [Kuninkaantie](/wiki/King%27s_Road_(Finland) "King's Road (Finland)"), or the "King's Road", ran through the area and two interesting medieval buildings were built here: [Vartiokylä hillfort](/w/index.php?title=Vartiokyl%C3%A4_hillfort&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vartiokylä hillfort (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vartiokyl%C3%A4n_linnavuori "fi:Vartiokylän linnavuori")\] in the 1380s and the [Church of St. Lawrence](/wiki/Church_of_St._Lawrence,_Vantaa "Church of St. Lawrence, Vantaa") in 1455. In the Middle Ages, several thousand people lived in Helsinki's [keep](/wiki/Keep "Keep").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

There was a lot of trade across the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"). The shipping route to the coast, and especially to [Reval](/wiki/Reval "Reval"), meant that by the end of the Middle Ages the Helsinki region had become an important trading centre for wealthy [peasants](/wiki/Peasant "Peasant"), [priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") and [nobles](/wiki/Nobility "Nobility") in Finland, after [Vyborg](/wiki/Vyborg "Vyborg") and [Pohja](/wiki/Pohja "Pohja"). [Furs](/wiki/Fur "Fur"), [wood](/wiki/Wood "Wood"), [tar](/wiki/Tar "Tar"), [fish](/wiki/Fish "Fish") and animals were exported from Helsinki, and [salt](/wiki/Salt "Salt") and [grain](/wiki/Grain "Grain") were brought to the fortress. Helsinki was also the most important cattle-breeding area in Uusimaa. With the help of trade, Helsinki became one of the wealthiest cities in Finland and Uusimaa. Thanks to trade and travel, e.g. to Reval, people could speak several languages, at least helpfully. Depending on the situation, Finnish, Swedish, Latin or Low German could be heard in the Helsinki area.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-40)^{#cite_ref-40}

Written chronicles from 1417 mention the village of [Koskela](/wiki/Koskela "Koskela") near the rapids at the mouth of the [River Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa_River "Vantaa River"), where Helsinki was to be founded.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-NKent-32)^{#cite_ref-NKent_32-2}  

### Founding of Helsinki {#Founding_of_Helsinki}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Founding of Helsinki")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Helsinki_Map_1645.png/170px-Helsinki_Map_1645.png)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_Map_1645.png) A map of Helsinki in 1645

Helsinki was founded by King [Gustav I of Sweden](/wiki/Gustav_I_of_Sweden "Gustav I of Sweden") on 12 June 1550 as a trading town called Helsingfors to rival the [Hanseatic](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League") city of Reval (now [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn")) on the southern shore of the [Gulf of Finland](/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland "Gulf of Finland").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Tabblo100-41)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-NKent-32)^ To populate the new town at the mouth of the [Vantaa River](/wiki/Vantaa_River "Vantaa River"), the king ordered the [bourgeoisie](/wiki/Bourgeoisie "Bourgeoisie") of [Porvoo](/wiki/Porvoo "Porvoo"), [Raseborg](/wiki/Raseborg "Raseborg"), [Rauma](/wiki/Rauma,_Finland "Rauma, Finland") and [Ulvila](/wiki/Ulvila "Ulvila") to [move](/wiki/Forced_displacement "Forced displacement") there.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-helsinki-history-42)^ The shallowness of the bay made it impossible to build a harbour, and the king allowed the settlers to leave the unfortunate location. In 1640, Count [Per Brahe the Younger](/wiki/Per_Brahe_the_Younger "Per Brahe the Younger"), together with some descendants of the original settlers, moved the centre of the city to the [Vironniemi](/wiki/Vironniemi "Vironniemi") peninsula by the sea, today's [Kruununhaka](/wiki/Kruununhaka "Kruununhaka") district, where the [Senate Square](/wiki/Senate_Square,_Helsinki "Senate Square, Helsinki") and [Helsinki Cathedral](/wiki/Helsinki_Cathedral "Helsinki Cathedral") are located.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-matkaoppaat-43)^{#cite_ref-matkaoppaat_43-0}

During the second half of the 17th century, Helsinki, as a wooden city, suffered from regular [fires](/wiki/Fire "Fire"), and by the beginning of the 18th century the population had fallen below 1,700. For a long time Helsinki was mainly a small administrative town for the governors of [Nyland and Tavastehus County](/wiki/Nyland_and_Tavastehus_County "Nyland and Tavastehus County"), but its importance began to grow in the 18th century when plans were made to build a more solid naval defence in front of the city.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-helsinki-history-42)^ Little came of these plans, however, as Helsinki remained a small town plagued by poverty, war and disease. The [plague](/wiki/Great_Northern_War_plague_outbreak "Great Northern War plague outbreak") of 1710 killed most of Helsinki's population.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Tabblo100-41)^ After the [Russians captured](/wiki/Battle_of_Helsinki_(1713) "Battle of Helsinki (1713)") Helsinki in May 1713 during the [Great Northern War](/wiki/Great_Northern_War "Great Northern War"), the retreating Swedish administration set fire to parts of the city.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-44)^^[\[43\]](#cite_note-45)^ Despite this, the city's population grew to 3,000 by the beginning of the 19th century. The construction of the naval fortress of [Sveaborg](/wiki/Suomenlinna "Suomenlinna") (*Viapori* in Finnish, now also called *Suomenlinna* ) in the 18th century helped to improve Helsinki's status. However, it wasn't until Russia defeated Sweden in the [Finnish War](/wiki/Finnish_War "Finnish War") and annexed Finland as the autonomous [Grand Duchy of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand Duchy of Finland") in 1809 that the city began to develop into a substantial city. The Russians besieged the Sveaborg fortress during the war, and about a quarter of the city was destroyed in a fire in 1808.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}

Emperor [Alexander I of Russia](/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia "Alexander I of Russia") moved the capital of Finland from [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku") to Helsinki on 8 April 1812 to reduce Swedish influence in Finland and bring the capital closer to [St Petersburg](/wiki/St_Petersburg "St Petersburg").^[\[45\]](#cite_note-47)^^[\[46\]](#cite_note-48)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-49)^ After the [Great Fire of Turku](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_Turku "Great Fire of Turku") in 1827, the [Royal Academy of Turku](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Turku "Royal Academy of Turku"), the only university in the country at the time, was also moved to Helsinki and eventually became the modern University of Helsinki. The move consolidated the city's new role and helped set it on a path of continuous growth. This transformation is most evident in the city centre, which was rebuilt in the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism") style to resemble St. Petersburg, largely according to a plan by the German-born architect [C. L. Engel](/wiki/Carl_Ludvig_Engel "Carl Ludvig Engel"). As elsewhere, technological advances such as the railway and [industrialisation](/wiki/Industrialisation "Industrialisation") were key factors in the city's growth.{#cite_ref-49}  

### Twentieth century {#Twentieth_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Twentieth century")\]

By the 1910s, Helsinki's population was already over 100,000, and despite the turbulence of Finnish history in the first half of the 20th century, Helsinki continued to grow steadily. This included the [Finnish Civil War](/wiki/Finnish_Civil_War "Finnish Civil War") and the [Winter War](/wiki/Winter_War "Winter War"), both of which left their mark on the city. At the beginning of the 20th century, there were roughly equal numbers of Finnish and [Swedish speakers](/wiki/Swedish-speaking_population_of_Finland "Swedish-speaking population of Finland") in Helsinki; the majority of workers were Finnish-speaking. The local [Helsinki slang](/wiki/Helsinki_slang "Helsinki slang") (or *stadin slangi* ) developed among Finnish children and young people from the 1890s as a mixed Finnish-Swedish language, with influences from [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") and [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"), and from the 1950s the slang began to become more Finnish.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-50)^ A landmark event was the [1952 Olympic Games](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics"), which were held in Helsinki. Finland's rapid urbanisation in the 1970s, which occurred late compared to the rest of Europe, tripled the population of the metropolitan area, and the [Helsinki Metro](/wiki/Helsinki_Metro "Helsinki Metro") subway system was built.{#cite_ref-50}

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Helsinki_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-26.jpg/220px-Helsinki_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-26.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-06-26.jpg) Helsinki seen from Sentinel-2  
Main article: [Geography of Helsinki](/wiki/Geography_of_Helsinki "Geography of Helsinki")

Known as the "Daughter of the Baltic"^[\[2\]](#cite_note-nickname1-2)^ or the "Pearl of the Baltic",^[\[3\]](#cite_note-nickname2-3)^^[\[49\]](#cite_note-51)^ Helsinki is located at the tip of a peninsula and on 315 islands. The city centre is located on a southern peninsula, *Helsinginniemi* ("Cape of Helsinki"), which is rarely referred to by its actual name, [Vironniemi](/wiki/Vironniemi "Vironniemi") ("Cape of Estonia"). Population density is comparatively high in certain parts of downtown Helsinki, reaching 16,494 inhabitants per square kilometre (42,720/sq mi) in the district of [Kallio](/wiki/Kallio "Kallio"), overall Helsinki's population density is 3,147 per square kilometre. Outside the city centre, much of Helsinki consists of post-war suburbs separated by patches of forest. A narrow, 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) long [Helsinki Central Park](/wiki/Central_Park_(Helsinki) "Central Park (Helsinki)"), which stretches from the city centre to Helsinki's northern border, is an important recreational area for residents. The City of Helsinki has about 11,000 boat [moorings](/wiki/Berth_(moorings) "Berth (moorings)") and over 14,000 hectares (35,000 acres; 54 square miles) of marine fishing waters adjacent to the capital region. About 60 species of fish are found in this area, and recreational fishing is popular.{#cite_ref-51}

Helsinki's main islands include [Seurasaari](/wiki/Seurasaari "Seurasaari"), [Lauttasaari](/wiki/Lauttasaari "Lauttasaari") and [Korkeasaari](/wiki/Korkeasaari "Korkeasaari") -- the latter is home to Finland's largest zoo, [Korkeasaari Zoo](/wiki/Korkeasaari_Zoo "Korkeasaari Zoo"). The former military islands of [Vallisaari](/wiki/Vallisaari "Vallisaari") and [Isosaari](/wiki/Isosaari "Isosaari") are now open to the public, but [Santahamina](/wiki/Santahamina "Santahamina") is still in military use. The most historic and remarkable island is the fortress of [Suomenlinna](/wiki/Suomenlinna "Suomenlinna") (Sveaborg).^[\[50\]](#cite_note-36h-52)^ The island of [Pihlajasaari](/wiki/Pihlajasaari "Pihlajasaari") is a popular summer resort, comparable to [Fire Island](/wiki/Fire_Island "Fire Island") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").{#cite_ref-36h_52-0}

There are 60 [nature reserves](/wiki/Nature_reserve "Nature reserve") in Helsinki with a total area of 95,480 acres (38,640 ha). Of the total area, 48,190 acres (19,500 ha) are water areas and 47,290 acres (19,140 ha) are land areas. The city also has seven nature reserves in [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo"), [Sipoo](/wiki/Sipoo "Sipoo"), [Hanko](/wiki/Hanko,_Finland "Hanko, Finland") and [Ingå](/wiki/Ing%C3%A5 "Ingå"). The largest nature reserve is the [Vanhankaupunginselkä](/wiki/Vanhankaupunginselk%C3%A4 "Vanhankaupunginselkä"), with an area of 30,600 acres (12,400 ha). The city's first nature reserve, Tiiraluoto of Lauttasaari, was established in 1948.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}

Helsinki's official plant is the [Norway maple](/wiki/Norway_maple "Norway maple") and its official animal is the [red squirrel](/wiki/Red_squirrel "Red squirrel").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}  

### Metropolitan area {#Metropolitan_area}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Metropolitan area")\]  
Main articles: [Helsinki capital region](/wiki/Helsinki_capital_region "Helsinki capital region") and [Helsinki metropolitan area](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Greater_Helsinki_Urban_Area.svg/220px-Greater_Helsinki_Urban_Area.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Greater_Helsinki_Urban_Area.svg) [Helsinki central urban area](/wiki/Helsinki_urban_area "Helsinki urban area"), an officially recognized [urban area](/wiki/Urban_areas_in_Finland "Urban areas in Finland") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/A_map_of_the_Capital_region_and_Greater_Helsinki_in_Finland.svg/220px-A_map_of_the_Capital_region_and_Greater_Helsinki_in_Finland.svg.png)](/wiki/File:A_map_of_the_Capital_region_and_Greater_Helsinki_in_Finland.svg) A map of Helsinki's capital region (in orange) and [its sub-regional municipalities](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area") (in light orange)

The [Helsinki capital region](/wiki/Helsinki_capital_region "Helsinki capital region") ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): *Pääkaupunkiseutu* , [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Huvudstadsregionen* ) comprises four municipalities: Helsinki, [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo"), [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa"), and [Kauniainen](/wiki/Kauniainen "Kauniainen").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-55)^ The [Helsinki urban area](/wiki/Helsinki_urban_area "Helsinki urban area") is considered to be the only [metropolis](/wiki/Metropolis "Metropolis") in [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland").^[\[54\]](#cite_note-56)^ It has a population of about 1.27 million, and is the most densely populated area of [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland"). The Capital Region spreads over a land area of 770 square kilometres (300 sq mi) and has a population density of 1,619 per sg km. With over 20 percent of the country's population in just 0.2 percent of its surface area, the area's housing density is high by Finnish standards.{#cite_ref-56}

The [Helsinki metropolitan area](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area") or the Greater Helsinki consists of the cities of the capital region and ten surrounding municipalities: [Hyvinkää](/wiki/Hyvink%C3%A4%C3%A4 "Hyvinkää"), [Järvenpää](/wiki/J%C3%A4rvenp%C3%A4%C3%A4 "Järvenpää"), [Kerava](/wiki/Kerava "Kerava"), [Kirkkonummi](/wiki/Kirkkonummi "Kirkkonummi"), [Nurmijärvi](/wiki/Nurmij%C3%A4rvi "Nurmijärvi"), [Sipoo](/wiki/Sipoo "Sipoo"), [Tuusula](/wiki/Tuusula "Tuusula"), [Pornainen](/wiki/Pornainen "Pornainen"), [Mäntsälä](/wiki/M%C3%A4nts%C3%A4l%C3%A4 "Mäntsälä") and [Vihti](/wiki/Vihti "Vihti").^[\[55\]](#cite_note-57)^ The Metropolitan Area covers 3,697 square kilometres (1,427 sq mi) and has a population of about 1.61 million, or about a fourth of the total population of Finland. The metropolitan area has a high concentration of employment: approximately 750,000 jobs.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-58)^ Despite the intensity of land use, the region also has large recreational areas and green spaces. The Helsinki metropolitan area is the world's northernmost urban area with a population of over one million people, and the northernmost EU capital city.{#cite_ref-58}

The [Helsinki urban area](/wiki/Helsinki_urban_area "Helsinki urban area") is an officially recognized [urban area in Finland](/wiki/Urban_areas_in_Finland "Urban areas in Finland"), defined by its population density. The area stretches throughout 11 municipalities, and is the largest such area in Finland, with a land area of 669.31 square kilometres (258.42 sq mi) and approximately 1.36 million inhabitants.  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Helsinki has a cold [hemiboreal](/wiki/Hemiboreal "Hemiboreal") [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfb* , [Trewartha](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification") *Dcbo* ).^[\[57\]](#cite_note-59)^ Due to the moderating influence of the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") and the [North Atlantic Current](/wiki/North_Atlantic_Current "North Atlantic Current") (see also [Extratropical cyclone](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical cyclone")), winter temperatures are higher than the northern location would suggest, with an average of −4 °C (25 °F) in January and February.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-fmiclimate-60)^{#cite_ref-fmiclimate_60-0}

Winters in Helsinki are significantly warmer than in the north of Finland, and the snow season in the capital is much shorter due to its location in the extreme south of Finland and the [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect. Temperatures below −20 °C (−4 °F) occur only a few times a year. However, due to the latitude, the days around the [winter solstice](/wiki/Winter_solstice "Winter solstice") are 5 hours and 48 minutes long, with the sun very low (at noon the sun is just over 6 degrees in the sky), and the cloudy weather at this time of year exacerbates the darkness. Conversely, Helsinki enjoys long days in summer, with 18 hours and 57 minutes of daylight around the [summer solstice](/wiki/Summer_solstice "Summer solstice").^[\[59\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}

The average maximum temperature from June to August is around 19 to 22 °C (66 to 72 °F). Due to the sea effect, especially on hot summer days, daytime temperatures are slightly cooler and nighttime temperatures higher than further inland. The highest temperature recorded in the city was 33.2 °C (91.8 °F) on 28 July 2019 at the [Kaisaniemi](/wiki/Kaisaniemi "Kaisaniemi") weather station,^[\[60\]](#cite_note-62)^ breaking the previous record of 33.1 °C (91.6 °F) set in July 1945 at the [Ilmala](/wiki/Ilmala "Ilmala") weather station.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-Suomen_Maakuntien_Ilmasto-63)^ The lowest temperature recorded in the city was −34.3 °C (−29.7 °F) on 10 January 1987, although an unofficial low of −35 °C (−31 °F) was recorded in December 1876.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-Helsinki_climate_table-64)^ [Helsinki Airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport") (in Vantaa, 17 km north of Helsinki city centre) recorded a maximum temperature of 33.7 °C (92.7 °F) on 29 July 2010 and a minimum of −35.9 °C (−33 °F) on 9 January 1987. Precipitation comes from frontal passages and thunderstorms. Thunderstorms are most common in summer.{#cite_ref-Helsinki_climate_table_64-0}

### Neighbourhoods and other subdivisions {#Neighbourhoods_and_other_subdivisions}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Neighbourhoods and other subdivisions")\]  
Main article: [Subdivisions of Helsinki](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Helsinki "Subdivisions of Helsinki")

Helsinki is divided into three major areas: [Helsinki Downtown](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Centre "Helsinki City Centre") ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): *Helsingin kantakaupunki* , [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Helsingfors innerstad* ), [North Helsinki](/wiki/North_Helsinki "North Helsinki") ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): *Pohjois-Helsinki* , [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Norra Helsingfors* ) and [East Helsinki](/wiki/East_Helsinki "East Helsinki") ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): *Itä-Helsinki* , [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Östra Helsingfors* ). Of these, Helsinki Downtown means the undefined core area of capital, as opposed to [suburbs](/wiki/Suburb "Suburb"). The designations [business center](/wiki/Central_business_district "Central business district") and city center usually refer to [Kluuvi](/wiki/Kluuvi "Kluuvi"), [Kamppi](/wiki/Kamppi "Kamppi") and [Punavuori](/wiki/Punavuori "Punavuori").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-70)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-71)^ Other subdivisional centers outside the downtown area include [Malmi](/wiki/Malmi,_Helsinki "Malmi, Helsinki") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Malm* ),^[\[70\]](#cite_note-72)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-73)^ located in the northeastern part of city, and [Itäkeskus](/wiki/It%C3%A4keskus "Itäkeskus") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Östra centrum* ),^[\[72\]](#cite_note-74)^ in the eastern part of city.{#cite_ref-74}  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  

### Neoclassical and romantic nationalism trend {#Neoclassical_and_romantic_nationalism_trend}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Neoclassical and romantic nationalism trend")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/West_side_of_Helsinki_Cathedral_in_Kruununhaka%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2022_April.jpg/220px-West_side_of_Helsinki_Cathedral_in_Kruununhaka%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2022_April.jpg)](/wiki/File:West_side_of_Helsinki_Cathedral_in_Kruununhaka,_Helsinki,_Finland,_2022_April.jpg) [Helsinki Cathedral](/wiki/Helsinki_Cathedral "Helsinki Cathedral") is among the most prominent buildings in the city [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Hotel_K%C3%A4mp_by_Night_in_Winter_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Hotel_K%C3%A4mp_by_Night_in_Winter_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hotel_K%C3%A4mp_by_Night_in_Winter_-_panoramio.jpg) [Hotel Kämp](/wiki/Hotel_K%C3%A4mp "Hotel Kämp"), a luxury hotel in Helsinki, located in [Kluuvi](/wiki/Kluuvi "Kluuvi")

[Carl Ludvig Engel](/wiki/Carl_Ludvig_Engel "Carl Ludvig Engel"), appointed to plan a new city centre on his own, designed several [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") buildings in Helsinki. The focal point of Engel's city plan was the [Senate Square](/wiki/Helsinki_Senate_Square "Helsinki Senate Square"). It is surrounded by the [Government Palace](/wiki/Government_Palace_(Finland) "Government Palace (Finland)") (to the east), the main building of Helsinki University (to the west), and (to the north) the large [Helsinki Cathedral](/wiki/Helsinki_Cathedral "Helsinki Cathedral"), which was finished in 1852, twelve years after Engel's death. Helsinki's [epithet](/wiki/Epithet "Epithet"), "The White City of the North", derives from this construction era. Most of Helsinki's older buildings were built after the 1808 fire; before that time, the oldest surviving building in the center of Helsinki is the [Sederholm House](/w/index.php?title=Sederholm_House&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sederholm House (page does not exist)") \[[fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_Sederholm "fr:Maison Sederholm")\] (1757) at the intersection of Senate Square and the Katariinankatu street.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-matkaoppaat-43)^ Suomenlinna also has buildings completed in the 18th century, including the [Kuninkaanportti](/wiki/Kuninkaanportti "Kuninkaanportti") on the [Kustaanmiekka Island](/wiki/Kustaanmiekka "Kustaanmiekka") \[[fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kustaanmiekka "fr:Kustaanmiekka")\] (1753--1754).^[\[73\]](#cite_note-75)^ The oldest church in Helsinki is the Östersundom church, built in 1754.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}

Helsinki is also home to numerous [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau")-influenced ([Jugend](/wiki/Jugendstil "Jugendstil") in Finnish) buildings belonging to the Kansallisromantiikka ([romantic nationalism](/wiki/Romantic_nationalism "Romantic nationalism")) trend, designed in the early 20th century and strongly influenced by *[Kalevala](/wiki/Kalevala "Kalevala")* , which was a common theme of the era. Helsinki's Art Nouveau style is also featured in central residential districts, such as [Katajanokka](/wiki/Katajanokka "Katajanokka") and [Ullanlinna](/wiki/Ullanlinna "Ullanlinna").^[\[75\]](#cite_note-77)^ An important architect of the Finnish Art Nouveau style was [Eliel Saarinen](/wiki/Eliel_Saarinen "Eliel Saarinen"), whose architectural masterpiece was the [Helsinki Central Station](/wiki/Helsinki_Central_railway_station "Helsinki Central railway station"). Opposite the [Bank of Finland](/wiki/Bank_of_Finland "Bank of Finland") building is the [Renaissance Revivalish](/wiki/Renaissance_Revival_architecture "Renaissance Revival architecture") the [House of the Estates](/wiki/House_of_the_Estates "House of the Estates") (1891).^[\[76\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

The only visible public buildings of the [Gothic Revival architecture](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") in Helsinki are [St. John's Church](/wiki/St._John%27s_Church,_Helsinki "St. John's Church, Helsinki") (1891) in Ullanlinna, which is the largest stone church in Finland, and its twin towers rise to 74 meters and have 2,600 seats.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-79)^ Other examples of neo-Gothic include the [House of Nobility](/wiki/House_of_Nobility_(Finland) "House of Nobility (Finland)") in [Kruununhaka](/wiki/Kruununhaka "Kruununhaka") and the [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic "Catholic") [St. Henry's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Henry%27s_Cathedral "St. Henry's Cathedral").^[\[78\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-81)^{#cite_ref-81}

In addition to other cities in Northern Europe that were not under the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), such as [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), Sweden, Helsinki's neoclassical buildings gained also popularity as a backdrop for scenes intended to depict the Soviet Union in numerous Hollywood movies during the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") era, when filming within the actual USSR was not possible. Some of them, including *[The Kremlin Letter](/wiki/The_Kremlin_Letter "The Kremlin Letter")* (1970), *[Reds](/wiki/Reds_(film) "Reds (film)")* (1981), and *[Gorky Park](/wiki/Gorky_Park_(film) "Gorky Park (film)")* (1983).^[\[80\]](#cite_note-82)^ was possible due to such Russian cities as [Leningrad](/wiki/Leningrad "Leningrad") and [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") also having similar neoclassical architecture. At the same time due to [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") and Finnish relations with the USSR the government secretly instructed Finnish officials not to extend assistance to such film projects.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-mtv3erittainsalainen-83)^ There are some films where Helsinki has been represented on its own in films, most notably the 1967 British-American [espionage](/wiki/Espionage_film "Espionage film") [thriller](/wiki/Thriller_film "Thriller film") *[Billion Dollar Brain](/wiki/Billion_Dollar_Brain "Billion Dollar Brain")* , starring [Michael Caine](/wiki/Michael_Caine "Michael Caine").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[83\]](#cite_note-85)^ The city has large amounts of underground areas such as shelters and tunnels, many used daily as swimming pool, church, water management, entertainment etc.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-86)^^[\[85\]](#cite_note-87)^^[\[86\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}  

### Functionalism and modern architecture {#Functionalism_and_modern_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Functionalism and modern architecture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Aleksanterinkatu_-_January_2018.jpg/220px-Aleksanterinkatu_-_January_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aleksanterinkatu_-_January_2018.jpg) [Aleksanterinkatu](/wiki/Aleksanterinkatu "Aleksanterinkatu") at Christmas time [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Oodi_July_2019_2.jpg/220px-Oodi_July_2019_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oodi_July_2019_2.jpg) The [Oodi](/wiki/Helsinki_Central_Library_Oodi "Helsinki Central Library Oodi") library is getting attention around the world.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-36h-52)^

Helsinki also features several buildings by Finnish architect [Alvar Aalto](/wiki/Alvar_Aalto "Alvar Aalto"),^[\[50\]](#cite_note-36h-52)^ recognized as one of the pioneers of architectural [functionalism](/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture) "Functionalism (architecture)"). However, some of his works, such as the headquarters of the paper company [Stora Enso](/wiki/Stora_Enso "Stora Enso") and the concert venue [Finlandia Hall](/wiki/Finlandia_Hall "Finlandia Hall"), have been subject to divided opinions from the citizens.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-89)^^[\[88\]](#cite_note-90)^^[\[89\]](#cite_note-penttilä-91)^{#cite_ref-penttilä_91-0}

Functionalist buildings in Helsinki by other architects include the [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium "Helsinki Olympic Stadium"), the [Tennis Palace](/wiki/Tennispalatsi "Tennispalatsi"), the [Rowing Stadium](/wiki/T%C3%B6%C3%B6l%C3%B6_Rowing_Stadium "Töölö Rowing Stadium"), the [Swimming Stadium](/wiki/Helsinki_Swimming_Stadium "Helsinki Swimming Stadium"), the [Velodrome](/wiki/Helsinki_Velodrome "Helsinki Velodrome"), the [Glass Palace](/wiki/Lasipalatsi "Lasipalatsi"), the [Töölö Sports Hall](/wiki/T%C3%B6%C3%B6l%C3%B6_Sports_Hall "Töölö Sports Hall"), and [Helsinki-Malmi Airport](/wiki/Helsinki-Malmi_Airport "Helsinki-Malmi Airport"). The sports venues were built to serve the 1940 Helsinki Olympic Games; the games were initially cancelled due to the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"), but the venues fulfilled their purpose in the [1952 Olympic Games](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics"). Many of them are listed by [DoCoMoMo](/wiki/DoCoMoMo "DoCoMoMo") as significant examples of modern architecture. [The Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium "Helsinki Olympic Stadium") and [Helsinki-Malmi Airport](/wiki/Helsinki-Malmi_Airport "Helsinki-Malmi Airport") are also catalogued by the [Finnish Heritage Agency](/wiki/Finnish_National_Board_of_Antiquities "Finnish National Board of Antiquities") as cultural-historical environments of national significance.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-92)^^[\[91\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Kalasatama_in_S%C3%B6rn%C3%A4inen%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2023_September_%E2%80%93_06.jpg/220px-Kalasatama_in_S%C3%B6rn%C3%A4inen%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2023_September_%E2%80%93_06.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kalasatama_in_S%C3%B6rn%C3%A4inen,_Helsinki,_Finland,_2023_September_%E2%80%93_06.jpg) Residential towers of [Kalasatama](/wiki/Kalasatama "Kalasatama"). The 134 m (440 ft) [Majakka](/wiki/Majakka "Majakka") has been built on top of the [Redi shopping centre](/wiki/Redi_(shopping_centre) "Redi (shopping centre)"). It is currently [Finland's tallest building](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Finland "List of tallest buildings in Finland").

When Finland became heavily urbanized in the 1960s and 1970s, the district of [Pihlajamäki](/wiki/Pihlajam%C3%A4ki "Pihlajamäki"), for example, was built in Helsinki for new residents, where for the first time in Finland, [precast concrete](/wiki/Precast_concrete "Precast concrete") was used on a large scale. [Pikku Huopalahti](/wiki/Pikku_Huopalahti "Pikku Huopalahti"), built in the 1980s and 1990s, has tried to get rid of a one-size-fits-all grid pattern, which means that its look is very organic and its streets are not repeated in the same way. [Itäkeskus](/wiki/It%C3%A4keskus "Itäkeskus") in [Eastern Helsinki](/wiki/Eastern_Helsinki "Eastern Helsinki") was the first regional center in the 1980s.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-ilonen-94)^ Efforts have also been made to protect Helsinki in the late 20th century, and many old buildings have been renovated.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-ilonen-94)^ [Modern architecture](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture") is represented, for example, by the Museum of Contemporary Art [Kiasma](/wiki/Kiasma "Kiasma"),^[\[50\]](#cite_note-36h-52)^ which consists of two straight and curved-walled parts, though this style strongly divided the opinions from the citizens.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-penttilä-91)^ Next to Kiasma is the glass-walled [Sanomatalo](/wiki/Sanomatalo "Sanomatalo") (1999).{#cite_ref-penttilä_91-1}

There have been many plans to build highrise buildings in Helsinki since the 1920s when architect Eliel Saarinen proposed the 85-meter-tall Kalevalatalo in 1921, but few tall buildings were built until the 21st century.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-95)^ In 1924 Oiva Kallio won Etu-Töölö competition with his plan (several 14- to 16-story buildings).^[\[94\]](#cite_note-96)^ A 32-story city hall was also proposed.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-97)^ Other plans of the 1930s included the 18-story "Kino" palace, a 17-story apartment building, and a 30-story ^[\[96\]](#cite_note-Pentti.murole@gmail.com-98)^ Stockmann building were proposed but only the 70-meter-tall 14-story [Hotel Torni](/wiki/Hotel_Torni "Hotel Torni") was built.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-99)^ (Hotel Torni was the tallest high-rise in Finland until 1976, when the 83-meter-tall [Neste headquarters](/wiki/Accountor_Tower "Accountor Tower") were completed in Espoo; Helsinki had rejected the tower.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-100)^) Twin 30-story buildings were proposed in [Pasila](/wiki/Pasila "Pasila") in the 1970s but were rejected.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-Pentti.murole@gmail.com-98)^ In 1990 a planned 104-meter-tall tower^[\[99\]](#cite_note-101)^^[\[100\]](#cite_note-102)^ for the [Kone](/wiki/Kone "Kone") company was also cancelled.{#cite_ref-102}

Highrise construction only started in the beginning of the 21st century, when the city decided to allow the construction of skyscrapers. Highrises were first built in [Kalasatama](/wiki/Kalasatama "Kalasatama"), a primarily-residential district built on [a former container port](/wiki/S%C3%B6rn%C3%A4inen_Harbour "Sörnäinen Harbour"). As of 2024, four residential towers have been completed: the 35-story, 282-apartment, 134-metre-tall (440 ft) [Majakka](/wiki/Majakka "Majakka") in 2019 (which is the [tallest building in Finland](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Finland "List of tallest buildings in Finland")); the 32-story, 124-meter Loisto in 2021; the 31-story, 120-meter Lumo One in 2022; and the 24-story, 98-meter Visio in 2023. The 26-story, 111-meter-tall office building Horisontti is to be completed in 2025, and three further towers are to be built in the complex.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-103)^^[\[102\]](#cite_note-104)^^[\[103\]](#cite_note-105)^ Tall residential towers have also been built in the eastern district of [Vuosaari](/wiki/Vuosaari "Vuosaari"): the 87-meter, 26-story [Cirrus](/wiki/Cirrus_(Helsinki_building) "Cirrus (Helsinki building)") was completed in 2006, the 24-story, 85-meter-tall Hyperion was completed in 2023 and the 33-story, 288-apartment, 120-meter-tall Atlas is due to be completed in late 2024.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

Skyscrapers have also be planned in the Pasila area, with a handful of over-100-meter-tall towers in various stages of planning or early construction as of 2024.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-107)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-108)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[108\]](#cite_note-110)^^[\[109\]](#cite_note-111)^ In [Jätkäsaari](/wiki/J%C3%A4tk%C3%A4saari "Jätkäsaari"), a 113-meter-tall hotel and a 24-story residential tower have been approved.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-112)^ 121- and 93-meter-tall office buildings are planned to be built in [Ruoholahti](/wiki/Ruoholahti "Ruoholahti").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-113)^ Well over 200 high-rise buildings will be built in Helsinki in the 2020s.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-114)^^\[*[failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")*\]^{#cite_ref-114}

The freshest building styles in Helsinki also include [low-carbon economy](/wiki/Low-carbon_economy "Low-carbon economy"); for example, the white-colored Katajanokan Laituri building that opened in [Katajanokka](/wiki/Katajanokka "Katajanokka") in the summer of 2024 is built from Finnish and Swedish wood. This building includes eco-friendly hotel Solo Sokos Pier 4.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}  

### Statues and sculptures {#Statues_and_sculptures}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Statues and sculptures")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/11-07-29-helsinki-by-RalfR-149.jpg/170px-11-07-29-helsinki-by-RalfR-149.jpg)](/wiki/File:11-07-29-helsinki-by-RalfR-149.jpg) A [statue](/wiki/Alexander_II_(statue_in_Helsinki) "Alexander II (statue in Helsinki)") of [Alexander II of Russia](/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia "Alexander II of Russia"), the [Grand Duke of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Finland "Grand Duke of Finland"), by [Walter Runeberg](/wiki/Walter_Runeberg "Walter Runeberg") and [Johannes Takanen](/w/index.php?title=Johannes_Takanen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Johannes Takanen (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Takanen "fi:Johannes Takanen")\] and erected in 1894. He was a well regarded [emperor](/wiki/Emperor "Emperor") among the majority of [Finns](/wiki/Finns "Finns") at the time.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-116)^

Well-known statues and monuments strongly embedded in the cityscape of Helsinki include the [Keisarinnankivi](/wiki/Keisarinnankivi "Keisarinnankivi") ("Stone of the Empress", 1835), the statue of Russian Emperor [Alexander II](/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia "Alexander II of Russia") (1894), the fountain sculpture *[Havis Amanda](/wiki/Havis_Amanda "Havis Amanda")* (1908), the [Paavo Nurmi statue](/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi_statue "Paavo Nurmi statue") (1925), the *[Three Smiths Statue](/wiki/Three_Smiths_Statue "Three Smiths Statue")* (1932), the [Aleksis Kivi Memorial](/wiki/Aleksis_Kivi_Memorial "Aleksis Kivi Memorial") (1939), the [Eino Leino Statue](/wiki/Eino_Leino_(statue) "Eino Leino (statue)") (1953), the [Equestrian statue of Marshal Mannerheim](/wiki/Equestrian_statue_of_Marshal_Mannerheim "Equestrian statue of Marshal Mannerheim") (1960) and the *[Sibelius Monument](/wiki/Sibelius_Monument_(Helsinki) "Sibelius Monument (Helsinki)")* (1967).^[\[115\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}  

Government {#Government}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Government")\]  
Main article: [City Council of Helsinki](/wiki/City_Council_of_Helsinki "City Council of Helsinki")  
Further information: [Helsinki (parliamentary electoral district)](/wiki/Helsinki_(parliamentary_electoral_district) "Helsinki (parliamentary electoral district)")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Helsinki_City_Hall_-_DSC03930.JPG/220px-Helsinki_City_Hall_-_DSC03930.JPG)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_City_Hall_-_DSC03930.JPG) The [Helsinki City Hall](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Hall "Helsinki City Hall") houses the [City Council of Helsinki](/wiki/City_Council_of_Helsinki "City Council of Helsinki").

As is the case with all [Finnish municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Finland "Municipalities of Finland"), [Helsinki's city council](/wiki/City_Council_of_Helsinki "City Council of Helsinki") is the main decision-making organ in local politics, dealing with issues such as [urban planning](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning"), schools, health care, and [public transport](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport"). The council is chosen in the nationally held [municipal elections](/wiki/Elections_in_Finland#Municipal_elections "Elections in Finland"), which are held every four years.

Helsinki's city council consists of eighty-five members. Following the most recent municipal elections in 2017, the three largest parties are the [National Coalition Party](/wiki/National_Coalition_Party "National Coalition Party") (25), the [Green League](/wiki/Green_League "Green League") (21), and the [Social Democratic Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Finland "Social Democratic Party of Finland") (12).^[\[116\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The Mayor of Helsinki is [Juhana Vartiainen](/wiki/Juhana_Vartiainen "Juhana Vartiainen").

[Historical population]

The city of Helsinki has 684,589 inhabitants, making it the most populous municipality in Finland and the third in the [Nordics](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries"). The [Helsinki region](/wiki/Helsinki_metropolitan_area "Helsinki metropolitan area") is the largest urbanised area in Finland with 1,606,104 inhabitants. The city of Helsinki is home to 12% of Finland's population. 19.9% of the population has a foreign background, which is twice above the national average. However, it is lower than in the major Finnish cities of [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo") or [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa").^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-0}

At 53 percent of the population, women form a greater proportion of Helsinki residents than the national average of 51 percent. Helsinki's population density of 3,147 people per square kilometre makes Helsinki the most densely-populated city in Finland. The life expectancy for men and women is slightly below the national averages: 75.1 years for men as compared to 75.7 years, 81.7 years for women as compared to 82.5 years.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[121\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

Helsinki has experienced strong growth since the 1810s, when it replaced [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku") as the capital of the [Grand Duchy of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand Duchy of Finland"), which later became the sovereign [Republic of Finland](/wiki/Republic_of_Finland "Republic of Finland"). The city continued its growth from that time on, with an exception during the [Finnish Civil War](/wiki/Finnish_Civil_War "Finnish Civil War"). From the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") up until the 1970s there was a massive exodus of people from the countryside to the cities of Finland, in particular Helsinki. Between 1944 and 1969 the population of the city nearly doubled from 275,000^[\[122\]](#cite_note-124)^ to 525,600.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-125)^{#cite_ref-125}

In the 1960s, the population growth of Helsinki began to decrease, mainly due to a lack of housing.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-126)^ Some residents began to move to the neighbouring cities of Espoo and Vantaa, resulting in increased population growth in both municipalities. Espoo's population increased ninefold in sixty years, from 22,874 people in 1950 to 244,353 in 2009.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-127)^ Vantaa saw an even more dramatic change in the same time span: from 14,976 in 1950 to 197,663 in 2009, a thirteenfold increase. These population changes prompted the municipalities of metropolitan area into more intense cooperation in areas such as public transportation^[\[126\]](#cite_note-128)^ -- resulting in the foundation of [HSL](/wiki/Helsinki_Regional_Transport_Authority "Helsinki Regional Transport Authority") -- and waste management.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-129)^ The increasing scarcity of housing and the higher costs of living in the capital region have pushed many daily commuters to find housing in formerly rural areas, and even further, to cities such as [Lohja](/wiki/Lohja "Lohja"), [Hämeenlinna](/wiki/H%C3%A4meenlinna "Hämeenlinna"), [Lahti](/wiki/Lahti "Lahti"), and [Porvoo](/wiki/Porvoo "Porvoo").{#cite_ref-129}

### Language {#Language}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Language")\]

Population by mother tongue (2023)^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-1}  
Finnish (75.0%)  
Swedish (5.5%)

The city of Helsinki is officially [bilingual](/wiki/Bilingual "Bilingual"), with both [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language") and [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language") as official languages. In 2023, the majority of the population, 75%, spoke Finnish as their [mother tongue](/wiki/First_language "First language"). There were 36,844 [Swedish speakers](/wiki/Swedish-speaking_population_of_Finland "Swedish-speaking population of Finland"), or 5.5% of the population. The number of people who speak [Sámi](/wiki/S%C3%A1mi_languages "Sámi languages"), Finland's third official language, is only 68 inhabitants. In Helsinki, 19.6% of the population speak a [mother tongue](/wiki/First_language "First language") other than Finnish or Swedish.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^ As [English](/wiki/English_language "English language") and [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language") are compulsory school subjects, functional bilingualism or trilingualism acquired through language studies is not uncommon.{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-2}

Although few people speak the Sámi languages as their mother tongue, there are 527 people of Sami origin.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-130)^ There are 93 Tatar speakers in Helsinki, almost half of the total number of Tatar speakers in Finland.{#cite_ref-130}

[Helsinki slang](/wiki/Helsinki_slang "Helsinki slang") is a regional dialect of the city. Historically, it was a combination of Finnish and Swedish, with influences from Russian and German. Nowadays it has a strong English influence. Today, however, Finnish is the common language of communication between Finnish speakers, Swedish speakers and speakers of other languages ([New Finns](/wiki/New_Finn "New Finn")) in everyday public life between strangers.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-131)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

The city of Helsinki and the national authorities have specifically targeted Swedish speakers. Knowledge of Finnish is essential in business and is usually a basic requirement in the labour market.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-yle.fi-133)^ Swedish speakers are most concentrated in the southern parts of the city. The district with the most Swedish speakers is [Ullanlinna/Ulrikasborg](/wiki/Ullanlinna "Ullanlinna") with 2,098 (19.6%), while [Byholmen](/w/index.php?title=Kyl%C3%A4saari&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kyläsaari (page does not exist)") is the only district where Swedish is the majority language (at 82.8%). The number of Swedish speakers decreased every year until 2008, and has increased every year since then. Since 2007, the number of Swedish speakers has increased by 2,351.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-134)^ In 1890, Finnish speakers overtook Swedish speakers to become the majority of the city's population.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-135)^ At that time, the population of Helsinki was 61,530.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}

The number of people with a foreign mother tongue is expected to reach 196,500 in 2035, representing 26% of the population. 114,000 will speak non-European languages, or 15% of the population.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-137)^ Today, at least 160 different languages are spoken in Helsinki. The most common foreign languages are [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") (3.1%), [Somali](/wiki/Somali_language "Somali language") (2.1%), [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") (1.5%), [English](/wiki/English_language "English language") (1.5%) and [Estonian](/wiki/Estonian_language "Estonian language") (1.4%).^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-3}

As of 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^, there were 134,084 people with an immigrant background living in Helsinki, or 20% of the population.^[\[c\]](#cite_note-139)^ There were 118,128 residents who were born abroad, or 17.5% of the population. The number of foreign citizens in Helsinki was 79,992.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-5}

The relative share of immigrants in Helsinki's population is twice the national average, and the city's new residents are increasingly of foreign origin.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^ This will increase the proportion of foreign residents in the coming years. As a crossroads of many international ports and Finland's [largest airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport"), Helsinki is the global gateway to and from Finland.{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-6}

Most foreign-born citizens come from the former [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia"), [Somalia](/wiki/Somalia "Somalia"), [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq"), and [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia").^[\[119\]](#cite_note-statistics-finland-population-2023-final-121)^{#cite_ref-statistics-finland-population-2023-final_121-7}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Religion")\]

In 2023, the [Evangelical Lutheran Church](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_Finland "Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland") was the largest religious group with 46.1% of the Helsinki population. Other religious groups made up 4.5% of the population. 49.4% of the population had no religious affiliation.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-140)^{#cite_ref-140}

The most important churches in Helsinki are [Helsinki Cathedral](/wiki/Helsinki_Cathedral "Helsinki Cathedral") (1852), [Uspenski Cathedral](/wiki/Uspenski_Cathedral "Uspenski Cathedral") (1868), [St. John's Church](/wiki/St._John%27s_Church,_Helsinki "St. John's Church, Helsinki") (1891), [Kallio Church](/wiki/Kallio_Church "Kallio Church") (1912) and [Temppeliaukio Church](/wiki/Temppeliaukio_Church "Temppeliaukio Church") (1969).

There are 21 Lutheran congregations in Helsinki, 18 of which are Finnish-speaking and 3 are Swedish-speaking. These form Helsinki's congregationgroup. Outside that there is Finland's German congregation with 3,000 members and Rikssvenska Olaus Petri-församlingen for Swedish-citizens with 1,000 members.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

The largest [Orthodox](/wiki/Orthodoxy "Orthodoxy") congregation is the Orthodox Church of Helsinki. It has 20,000 members. Its main church is the [Uspenski Cathedral](/wiki/Uspenski_Cathedral "Uspenski Cathedral").^[\[139\]](#cite_note-142)^ The two largest [Catholic](/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism") congregations are the [Cathedral of Saint Henry](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Saint_Henry "Cathedral of Saint Henry"), with 4,552 members, established in 1860 and [St Mary's Catholic Parish](/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Church,_Helsinki "St. Mary's Church, Helsinki"), with 4,107 members, established in 1954.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Helsinki_Helsingfors_Synagogue_02.png/220px-Helsinki_Helsingfors_Synagogue_02.png)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_Helsingfors_Synagogue_02.png) [Helsinki Synagogue](/wiki/Helsinki_Synagogue "Helsinki Synagogue") in 2020

There are around 30 mosques in the Helsinki region. Many linguistic and ethnic groups such as [Bangladeshis](/wiki/Bangladeshis "Bangladeshis"), [Kosovars](/wiki/Kosovo_Albanians "Kosovo Albanians"), [Kurds](/wiki/Kurds "Kurds") and [Bosniaks](/wiki/Bosniaks "Bosniaks") have established their own mosques.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-144)^ The largest congregation in both Helsinki and Finland is the [Helsinki Islamic Center](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki_Islamic_Center&action=edit&redlink=1 "Helsinki Islamic Center (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki_Islam_Keskus "fi:Helsinki Islam Keskus")\], established in 1995. It has over 2,800 members as of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^, and it received €24,131 in government assistance.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}

In 2015, imam [Anas Hajar](/w/index.php?title=Anas_Hajar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Anas Hajar (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anas_Hajjar "fi:Anas Hajjar")\] estimated that on big celebrations around 10,000 Muslims visit mosques.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-146)^ In 2004, it was estimated that there were 8,000 Muslims in Helsinki, 1.5% of the population at the time.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-147)^ The number of people in Helsinki with a background from Muslim majority countries was nearly 41,000 as of 2021, representing over 6% of the population.{#cite_ref-147}

The main synagogue of Helsinki is the [Helsinki Synagogue](/wiki/Helsinki_Synagogue "Helsinki Synagogue") from 1906, located in [Kamppi](/wiki/Kamppi "Kamppi"). It has over 1,200 members, out of the 1,800 [Jews in Finland](/wiki/Jews_in_Finland "Jews in Finland"), and it is the older of the two buildings in Finland originally built as a synagogue, followed by the [Turku Synagogue](/wiki/Turku_Synagogue "Turku Synagogue") in 1912.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-148)^ The congregation includes a synagogue, Jewish kindergarten, school, library, Jewish meat shop, two Jewish cemeteries and an retirement home. Many Jewish organizations and societies are based there, and the synagogue publishes the main Jewish magazine in Finland, *[HaKehila](/w/index.php?title=HaKehila&action=edit&redlink=1 "HaKehila (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/HaKehila "fi:HaKehila")\]* .^[\[146\]](#cite_note-149)^{#cite_ref-149}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Kamppi_Center_II.jpg/220px-Kamppi_Center_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kamppi_Center_II.jpg) [Kamppi Center](/wiki/Kamppi_Center "Kamppi Center"), a shopping and transportation complex in [Kamppi](/wiki/Kamppi "Kamppi")

Helsinki metropolitan area generates approximately one third of Finland's GDP. GDP per capita is roughly 1.3 times the national average.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-150)^ Helsinki profits on serviced-related IT and public sectors. Having moved from heavy industrial works, shipping companies also employ a substantial number of people.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-151)^{#cite_ref-151}

The metropolitan area's gross value added per capita is 200% of the mean of 27 European metropolitan areas, equalling those of Stockholm and Paris. The gross value added annual growth has been around 4%.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}

83 of the 100 largest Finnish companies have their headquarters in the metropolitan area. Two-thirds of the 200 highest-paid Finnish executives live in the metropolitan area and 42% in Helsinki. The average income of the top 50 earners was 1.65 million euro.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}

The tap water is of excellent quality and it is supplied by the 120 km (75 mi) [Päijänne Water Tunnel](/wiki/P%C3%A4ij%C3%A4nne_Water_Tunnel "Päijänne Water Tunnel"), one of the world's longest continuous rock tunnels.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

Helsinki has 190 comprehensive schools, 41 upper secondary schools, and 15 vocational institutes. Half of the 41 upper secondary schools are private or state-owned, the other half municipal. \[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Museums")\]

The biggest historical museum in Helsinki is the [National Museum of Finland](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Finland "National Museum of Finland"), which displays a vast collection from prehistoric times to the 21st century. The museum building itself, a national romantic-style neomedieval castle, is a tourist attraction. Another major historical museum is the [Helsinki City Museum](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Museum "Helsinki City Museum"), which introduces visitors to Helsinki's 500-year history. The [University of Helsinki](/wiki/University_of_Helsinki "University of Helsinki") also has many significant museums, including the [Helsinki University Museum](/wiki/Helsinki_University_Museum "Helsinki University Museum") "Arppeanum" and the [Finnish Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Finnish_Museum_of_Natural_History "Finnish Museum of Natural History").

The [Finnish National Gallery](/wiki/Finnish_National_Gallery "Finnish National Gallery") consists of three museums: [Ateneum Art Museum](/wiki/Ateneum "Ateneum") for classical Finnish art, [Sinebrychoff Art Museum](/wiki/Sinebrychoff_Art_Museum "Sinebrychoff Art Museum") for classical European art, and [Kiasma Art Museum](/wiki/Kiasma "Kiasma") for modern art, in a building by architect [Steven Holl](/wiki/Steven_Holl "Steven Holl"). The old Ateneum, a neo-Renaissance palace from the 19th century, is one of the city's major historical buildings. All three museum buildings are [state-owned](/wiki/State-owned "State-owned") through [Senate Properties](/wiki/Senate_Properties "Senate Properties").

The city of Helsinki hosts its own art collection in the [Helsinki Art Museum](/wiki/Helsinki_Art_Museum "Helsinki Art Museum") (HAM), primarily located in its [Tennispalatsi](/wiki/Tennispalatsi "Tennispalatsi") gallery. Around 200 pieces of public art lie outside. The art is all city property.

[Helsinki Art Museum](/wiki/Helsinki_Art_Museum "Helsinki Art Museum") will in 2020 launch the Helsinki Biennial, which will bring art to maritime Helsinki -- in its first year to the island of [Vallisaari](/wiki/Vallisaari "Vallisaari").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}

The [Design Museum](/wiki/Design_Museum,_Helsinki "Design Museum, Helsinki") is devoted to the exhibition of both Finnish and foreign design, including industrial design, fashion, and graphic design. Other museums in Helsinki include the [Military Museum of Finland](/wiki/Military_Museum_of_Finland "Military Museum of Finland"), [Didrichsen Art Museum](/wiki/Didrichsen_Art_Museum "Didrichsen Art Museum"), [Amos Rex Art Museum](/wiki/Amos_Anderson_Art_Museum "Amos Anderson Art Museum"), and the [Tram Museum](/w/index.php?title=Tram_Museum&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tram Museum (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ratikkamuseo "fi:Ratikkamuseo")\].
