### Theatres {#Theatres}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Theatres")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Helsinki_-_Finnish_National_Theatre_and_the_Finnish_National_Writer_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Helsinki_-_Finnish_National_Theatre_and_the_Finnish_National_Writer_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_-_Finnish_National_Theatre_and_the_Finnish_National_Writer_-_panoramio.jpg) The [Finnish National Theatre](/wiki/Finnish_National_Theatre "Finnish National Theatre") (1902), designed by architect Onni Tarjanne. In front of it, the [memorial statue of Aleksis Kivi](/wiki/Aleksis_Kivi_Memorial "Aleksis Kivi Memorial").

Helsinki has three major theatres: The [Finnish National Theatre](/wiki/Finnish_National_Theatre "Finnish National Theatre"), the [Helsinki City Theatre](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Theatre "Helsinki City Theatre"), and the [Swedish Theatre](/wiki/Swedish_Theatre "Swedish Theatre") (*Svenska Teatern* ). Other notable theatres in the city include the [Alexander Theatre](/wiki/Alexander_Theatre "Alexander Theatre"), *[Q-teatteri](/w/index.php?title=Q-teatteri&action=edit&redlink=1 "Q-teatteri (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-teatteri "fi:Q-teatteri")\]* , [Savoy Theatre](/w/index.php?title=Savoy_Theatre_(Helsinki)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Savoy Theatre (Helsinki) (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savoy-teatteri "fi:Savoy-teatteri")\], [KOM-theatre](/w/index.php?title=KOM-theatre&action=edit&redlink=1 "KOM-theatre (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOM-teatteri "fi:KOM-teatteri")\], and *[Teatteri Jurkka](/w/index.php?title=Teatteri_Jurkka&action=edit&redlink=1 "Teatteri Jurkka (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teatteri_Jurkka "fi:Teatteri Jurkka")\]*.  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Music")\]

Helsinki is home to two full-size symphony orchestras, the [Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Helsinki_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra") and the [Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Finnish_Radio_Symphony_Orchestra "Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra"), both of which perform at the [Helsinki Music Centre](/wiki/Helsinki_Music_Centre "Helsinki Music Centre") concert hall. Acclaimed contemporary composers [Kaija Saariaho](/wiki/Kaija_Saariaho "Kaija Saariaho"), [Magnus Lindberg](/wiki/Magnus_Lindberg_(Finnish_composer) "Magnus Lindberg (Finnish composer)"), [Esa-Pekka Salonen](/wiki/Esa-Pekka_Salonen "Esa-Pekka Salonen"), and [Einojuhani Rautavaara](/wiki/Einojuhani_Rautavaara "Einojuhani Rautavaara"), among others, were born and raised in Helsinki, and studied at the [Sibelius Academy](/wiki/Sibelius_Academy "Sibelius Academy"). The [Finnish National Opera](/wiki/Finnish_National_Opera "Finnish National Opera"), the only full-time, professional opera company in Finland, is located in Helsinki. The opera singer [Martti Wallén](/wiki/Martti_Wall%C3%A9n "Martti Wallén"), one of the company's long-time soloists, was born and raised in Helsinki, as was mezzo-soprano [Monica Groop](/wiki/Monica_Groop "Monica Groop").

Many widely renowned and acclaimed bands have originated in Helsinki, including [Children of Bodom](/wiki/Children_of_Bodom "Children of Bodom"), [Hanoi Rocks](/wiki/Hanoi_Rocks "Hanoi Rocks"), [HIM](/wiki/HIM_(Finnish_band) "HIM (Finnish band)"), [Stratovarius](/wiki/Stratovarius "Stratovarius"), [The 69 Eyes](/wiki/The_69_Eyes "The 69 Eyes"), [Finntroll](/wiki/Finntroll "Finntroll"), [Ensiferum](/wiki/Ensiferum "Ensiferum"), [Wintersun](/wiki/Wintersun "Wintersun"), [The Rasmus](/wiki/The_Rasmus "The Rasmus"), [Poets of the Fall](/wiki/Poets_of_the_Fall "Poets of the Fall"), and [Apocalyptica](/wiki/Apocalyptica "Apocalyptica"). The most significant of the [metal music](/wiki/Metal_music "Metal music") events in Helsinki is the [Tuska Open Air Metal Festival](/wiki/Tuska_Open_Air_Metal_Festival "Tuska Open Air Metal Festival") in [Suvilahti](/wiki/Suvilahti "Suvilahti"), [Sörnäinen](/wiki/S%C3%B6rn%C3%A4inen "Sörnäinen").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-157)^{#cite_ref-157}

The city's main musical venues are the [Finnish National Opera](/wiki/Finnish_National_Opera "Finnish National Opera"), the [Finlandia concert hall](/wiki/Finlandia_Hall "Finlandia Hall"), and the [Helsinki Music Centre](/wiki/Helsinki_Music_Centre "Helsinki Music Centre"). The Music Centre also houses a part of the [Sibelius Academy](/wiki/Sibelius_Academy "Sibelius Academy"). Bigger concerts and events are usually held at one of the city's two big ice hockey arenas: the [Helsinki Halli](/wiki/Helsinki_Halli "Helsinki Halli") or the [Helsinki Ice Hall](/wiki/Helsinki_Ice_Hall "Helsinki Ice Hall"). Helsinki has Finland's largest fairgrounds, the [Messukeskus Helsinki](/wiki/Messukeskus_Helsinki "Messukeskus Helsinki"), which is attended by more than a million visitors a year.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

[Helsinki Arena](/wiki/Helsinki_Arena "Helsinki Arena") hosted the [Eurovision Song Contest 2007](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2007 "Eurovision Song Contest 2007"), the first [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") arranged in Finland, following [Lordi](/wiki/Lordi "Lordi")'s win in [2006](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2006 "Eurovision Song Contest 2006").^[\[156\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}  

### Art {#Art}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Art")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/%22Havis_Amanda%22%2C_la_statue_de_la_fontaine_de_Vallgren_%28Helsinki%29_%282744386193%29.jpg/150px-%22Havis_Amanda%22%2C_la_statue_de_la_fontaine_de_Vallgren_%28Helsinki%29_%282744386193%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%22Havis_Amanda%22,_la_statue_de_la_fontaine_de_Vallgren_(Helsinki)_(2744386193).jpg) *[Havis Amanda](/wiki/Havis_Amanda "Havis Amanda")* , a fountain sculpture at the [Helsinki Market Square](/wiki/Helsinki_Market_Square "Helsinki Market Square")

[Helsinki Day](/wiki/Helsinki_Day "Helsinki Day") (*Helsinki-päivä* ) will be celebrated every 12 June, with numerous entertainment events culminating in an [open-air concert](/wiki/Open-air_concert "Open-air concert").^[\[157\]](#cite_note-160)^^[\[158\]](#cite_note-161)^ Also, the [Helsinki Festival](/wiki/Helsinki_Festival "Helsinki Festival") is an arts and culture festival that takes place every August (including the [Night of the Arts](/wiki/Night_of_the_Arts "Night of the Arts")).^[\[159\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}

At the [Senate Square](/wiki/Helsinki_Senate_Square "Helsinki Senate Square") in fall 2010, Finland's largest open-air art exhibition to date took place: About 1.4 million people saw the international exhibition of *[United Buddy Bears](/wiki/United_Buddy_Bears "United Buddy Bears")* .^[\[160\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}

Helsinki was the 2012 [World Design Capital](/wiki/World_Design_Capital "World Design Capital"), in recognition of the use of design as an effective tool for social, cultural, and economic development in the city. In choosing Helsinki, the World Design Capital selection jury highlighted Helsinki's use of 'Embedded Design', which has tied design in the city to innovation, "creating global brands, such as [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia"), [Kone](/wiki/Kone "Kone"), and [Marimekko](/wiki/Marimekko "Marimekko"), popular events, like the annual [Helsinki Design Week](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki_Design_Week&action=edit&redlink=1 "Helsinki Design Week (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki_Design_Week "fi:Helsinki Design Week")\], outstanding education and research institutions, such as the [Aalto University School of Arts, Design and Architecture](/wiki/Aalto_University_School_of_Arts,_Design_and_Architecture "Aalto University School of Arts, Design and Architecture"), and exemplary architects and designers such as [Eliel Saarinen](/wiki/Eliel_Saarinen "Eliel Saarinen") and [Alvar Aalto](/wiki/Alvar_Aalto "Alvar Aalto")".^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Worlddesigncapital.com-14)^{#cite_ref-Worlddesigncapital.com_14-1}

Helsinki hosts many film festivals. Most of them are small venues, while some have generated interest internationally. The most prolific of these is the [Helsinki International Film Festival -- Love \& Anarchy](/wiki/Helsinki_International_Film_Festival "Helsinki International Film Festival") film festival, also known as Helsinki International Film Festival, which features films on a wide spectrum. [Night Visions](/wiki/Night_Visions_(film_festival) "Night Visions (film festival)"), on the other hand, focuses on genre cinema, screening [horror](/wiki/Horror_film "Horror film"), [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy "Fantasy"), and [science fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction") films in very popular movie marathons that last the entire night. Another popular film festival is [DocPoint](/w/index.php?title=DocPoint_(film_festival)&action=edit&redlink=1 "DocPoint (film festival) (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/DocPoint_%E2%80%93_Helsingin_dokumenttielokuvafestivaali "fi:DocPoint – Helsingin dokumenttielokuvafestivaali")\], a festival that focuses solely on [documentary](/wiki/Documentary_film "Documentary film") cinema.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-164)^^[\[162\]](#cite_note-165)^^[\[163\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Media")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Sanomatalo_-_Helsinki_-_13.9.2013.jpg/220px-Sanomatalo_-_Helsinki_-_13.9.2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sanomatalo_-_Helsinki_-_13.9.2013.jpg) Sanomatalo, a current office building of [Sanoma Corporation](/wiki/Sanoma_Corporation "Sanoma Corporation")

Today,^\[*[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")*\]^ there are around 200 newspapers, 320 popular magazines, 2,100 professional magazines, 67 commercial radio stations, three [digital radio](/wiki/Digital_radio "Digital radio") channels, and one nationwide and five national [public service radio channels](/wiki/Public_broadcasting "Public broadcasting").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

[Sanoma](/wiki/Sanoma "Sanoma") publishes Finland's [journal of record](/wiki/Newspaper_of_record "Newspaper of record"), *[Helsingin Sanomat](/wiki/Helsingin_Sanomat "Helsingin Sanomat")*, the [tabloid](/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format) "Tabloid (newspaper format)") *[Ilta-Sanomat](/wiki/Ilta-Sanomat "Ilta-Sanomat")* , the commerce-oriented *[Taloussanomat](/wiki/Taloussanomat "Taloussanomat")* , and the television channel [Nelonen](/wiki/Nelonen_(television) "Nelonen (television)"). Another Helsinki-based media house, [Alma Media](/wiki/Alma_Media "Alma Media"), publishes over thirty magazines, including the tabloid *[Iltalehti](/wiki/Iltalehti "Iltalehti")* , and the commerce-oriented *[Kauppalehti](/wiki/Kauppalehti "Kauppalehti")*.

Finland's national public-broadcasting institution [Yle](/wiki/Yle "Yle") operates five television channels and thirteen radio channels in both national languages. Yle is headquartered in the neighbourhood of [Pasila](/wiki/Pasila "Pasila"). All TV channels are broadcast [digitally](/wiki/Digital_television "Digital television"), both terrestrially and on cable. Yle's studio area houses the 146-metre (479 ft) high television and radio tower, [Yle Transmission Tower](/wiki/Yle_Transmission_Tower "Yle Transmission Tower") (*Pasilan linkkitorni* ),^[\[164\]](#cite_note-167)^ which is the third tallest structure in Helsinki and one of Helsinki's most famous landmarks, from the top of which, in good weather, can be seen even as far as [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn") over the Gulf of Finland.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-168)^{#cite_ref-168}

The commercial television channel [MTV3](/wiki/MTV3 "MTV3") and commercial radio channel [Radio Nova](/wiki/Radio_Nova_(Finland) "Radio Nova (Finland)") are owned by [Nordic Broadcasting](/wiki/Nordic_Broadcasting "Nordic Broadcasting") ([Bonnier](/wiki/Bonnier_Group "Bonnier Group") and [Proventus](/wiki/Proventus "Proventus")).  
Further information: [Dubberman Finland](/wiki/Dubberman_Finland "Dubberman Finland")  

### Food {#Food}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Food")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Ekbergin_kahvila_ja_leipomon_myym%C3%A4l%C3%A4-_Bulevardi_9_-_Kamppi_-_Helsinki_-_m.jpg/220px-Ekbergin_kahvila_ja_leipomon_myym%C3%A4l%C3%A4-_Bulevardi_9_-_Kamppi_-_Helsinki_-_m.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ekbergin_kahvila_ja_leipomon_myym%C3%A4l%C3%A4-_Bulevardi_9_-_Kamppi_-_Helsinki_-_m.jpg) [Café Ekberg](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Ekberg "Café Ekberg"), the oldest coffeehouse of Helsinki, along the [Bulevardi](/wiki/Bulevardi "Bulevardi") in the [Kamppi](/wiki/Kamppi "Kamppi") district

Helsinki was already known in the 18th century for its abundant number of [inns](/wiki/Inn "Inn") and [pubs](/wiki/Pub "Pub"), where both locals and those who landed in the harbor were offered plenty of [alcoholic beverages](/wiki/Alcoholic_drink "Alcoholic drink").^[\[166\]](#cite_note-alcohol-169)^ At that time, taxes on the sale of alcohol were a very significant source of income for Helsinki, and one of the most important sellers of alcohol was [Johan Sederholm](/w/index.php?title=Johan_Sederholm&action=edit&redlink=1 "Johan Sederholm (page does not exist)") \[[fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_Sederholm "fr:Johan Sederholm")\] (1722--1805), a trade councilor who attracted rural [merchants](/wiki/Merchant "Merchant") with alcohol and made good deals.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-alcohol-169)^ Gradually, a new kind of beverage culture began to grow in the next century, and as early as 1852, the first [café](/wiki/Coffeehouse "Coffeehouse") of Finland, [Café Ekberg](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Ekberg "Café Ekberg"),^[\[167\]](#cite_note-170)^^[\[168\]](#cite_note-171)^ was established by confectioner [Fredrik Ekberg](/w/index.php?title=Fredrik_Ekberg&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fredrik Ekberg (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fredrik_Ekberg "fi:Fredrik Ekberg")\] (1825--1891) after attending his studies in [St. Petersburg](/wiki/St._Petersburg "St. Petersburg"). Ekberg has also been said to have created Finland's "national [pastry](/wiki/Pastry "Pastry") tradition".^[\[169\]](#cite_note-172)^ At first, café culture was only a prerogative of sophisticated [elite](/wiki/Elite "Elite"), when it recently began to take shape as the right of every man.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-173)^ Today, there are several hundred cafés in Helsinki, the most notable of which is [Cafe Regatta](/wiki/Cafe_Regatta "Cafe Regatta"), which is very popular with foreign tourists.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-174)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-175)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-176)^{#cite_ref-176}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Markthalle_Fisch.JPG/220px-Markthalle_Fisch.JPG)](/wiki/File:Markthalle_Fisch.JPG) Fish for sale in the [Old Market Hall](/wiki/Old_Market_Hall,_Helsinki "Old Market Hall, Helsinki") (*Vanha kauppahalli*)

As an important [port city](/wiki/Port_city "Port city") on the Baltic Sea, Helsinki has long been known for its [fish food](/wiki/Fish_as_food "Fish as food"), and it has recently started to become one of the leading fish food capitals in [Northern Europe](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe").^[\[174\]](#cite_note-kosmos-177)^ Helsinki's [Market Square](/wiki/Market_Square,_Helsinki "Market Square, Helsinki") is especially known for its traditional [herring](/wiki/Herring "Herring") market, which has been organized since 1743.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-178)^^[\[176\]](#cite_note-179)^^[\[177\]](#cite_note-180)^^[\[178\]](#cite_note-helsinki-food-181)^ [Salmon](/wiki/Salmon "Salmon") is also a typical Helsinki fish dish, both fried and [souped](/wiki/Fish_soup "Fish soup").^[\[179\]](#cite_note-182)^ The most prestigious restaurants specializing in [seafood](/wiki/Seafood "Seafood") include Restaurant Fisken på Disken.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-183)^^[\[181\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ty%C3%B6pajankatu_2%2C_Tynnyrintekij%C3%A4nkatu_-_Helsinki_2016_-_G3634_-_hkm.HKMS000005-km0000okav.jpg/220px-Ty%C3%B6pajankatu_2%2C_Tynnyrintekij%C3%A4nkatu_-_Helsinki_2016_-_G3634_-_hkm.HKMS000005-km0000okav.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ty%C3%B6pajankatu_2,_Tynnyrintekij%C3%A4nkatu_-_Helsinki_2016_-_G3634_-_hkm.HKMS000005-km0000okav.jpg) A terrace of the Restaurant Roslund at the [Teurastamo](/wiki/Teurastamo "Teurastamo") area

Helsinki is currently experiencing a period of booming [food culture](/wiki/Food_culture "Food culture"), and it has developed into an internationally acclaimed food city, receiving recognition for promoting food culture.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-helsinki-food-181)^^[\[182\]](#cite_note-185)^^[\[183\]](#cite_note-186)^ The local food culture is made up of cuisines from around the world and the fusions they form. Various [Asian restaurants](/wiki/Asian_cuisine "Asian cuisine") such as [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine "Chinese cuisine"), [Thai](/wiki/Thai_cuisine "Thai cuisine"), [Indian](/wiki/Indian_cuisine "Indian cuisine") and [Nepalese](/wiki/Nepalese_cuisine "Nepalese cuisine") are particularly prominent in Helsinki's cityscape, but over the past couple of years, restaurants serving [Vietnamese](/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine "Vietnamese cuisine") food have been very popular.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-kosmos-177)^ [Sushi](/wiki/Sushi "Sushi") [restaurant buffets](/wiki/Restaurant_buffets "Restaurant buffets") have also made their way into the city's restaurant offerings in one fell swoop.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-kosmos-177)^ The third prominent trend is restaurants serving pure local food, many of which specialize primarily in serving pure [Nordic flavors](/wiki/Nordic_cuisine "Nordic cuisine").^[\[174\]](#cite_note-kosmos-177)^ In past years [Middle Eastern](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine "Middle Eastern cuisine") food culture rose in its popularity. Especially Helsinki's eastern part offers many different options for Middle Eastern cuisine lovers.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-187)^ There is also some touches of [Russian cuisine](/wiki/Russian_cuisine "Russian cuisine"), one of which is the Finnish version of *[blinis](/wiki/Blini "Blini")* , a thick [pancakes](/wiki/Pancake "Pancake") that are usually fried in a cast-iron pan.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-188)^ One of the most significant food culture venues in Helsinki is the general public area known as [Teurastamo](/wiki/Teurastamo "Teurastamo") in the [Hermanni](/wiki/Hermanni_(Helsinki) "Hermanni (Helsinki)") district, which operated as the city's [slaughterhouse](/wiki/Slaughterhouse "Slaughterhouse") between 1933 and 1992, to which the name of the place also refers.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-helsinki-food-181)^^[\[186\]](#cite_note-189)^^[\[187\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

A nationwide food carnival called Restaurant Day (*Ravintolapäivä* ) has begun in Helsinki and has traditionally been celebrated since May 2011.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-191)^ The purpose of the day is to have fun, share new food experiences and enjoy the common environment with the group.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-helsinki-food-181)^{#cite_ref-helsinki-food_181-3}  

### Other {#Other}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Other")\]

[Vappu](/wiki/Vappu "Vappu") is an annual carnival for students and workers on 1 May. The last week of June marks the [Helsinki Pride](/wiki/Helsinki_Pride "Helsinki Pride") [human rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights") event, which was attended by 100,000 marchers in 2018.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-192)^{#cite_ref-192}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Helsinki](/wiki/Sport_in_Helsinki "Sport in Helsinki")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/2005_World_Championships_in_Athletics_2.jpg/220px-2005_World_Championships_in_Athletics_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:2005_World_Championships_in_Athletics_2.jpg) The [Helsinki Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium "Helsinki Olympic Stadium") was the centre of activities during the [1952 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium_Tower.jpg/220px-Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium_Tower.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_Olympic_Stadium_Tower.jpg) Helsinki Olympic Stadium Tower

Helsinki has a long tradition of sports: the city gained much of its initial international recognition during the [1952 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics"), and the city has arranged sporting events such as the first [World Championships in Athletics](/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "IAAF World Championships in Athletics") 1983 and 2005, and the European Championships in Athletics 1971, 1994, and 2012. Helsinki hosts successful local teams in both of the most popular team sports in Finland: [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") and [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey"). Helsinki houses [HJK Helsinki](/wiki/HJK_Helsinki "HJK Helsinki"), Finland's largest and most successful football club, and [IFK Helsingfors](/wiki/HIFK_Fotboll "HIFK Fotboll"), their local rivals with 7 championship titles. The fixtures between the two are commonly known as [Stadin derby](/wiki/Stadin_derby "Stadin derby"). Helsinki's track and field club Helsingin Kisa-Veikot is also dominant within Finland. Ice hockey is popular among many Helsinki residents, who usually support either of the local clubs [IFK Helsingfors](/wiki/HIFK_(ice_hockey) "HIFK (ice hockey)") (HIFK) or [Jokerit](/wiki/Jokerit "Jokerit"). HIFK, with 14 Finnish championships titles, also plays in the highest [bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy") division,^[\[190\]](#cite_note-193)^ along with [Botnia-69](/wiki/Botnia-69 "Botnia-69"). The Olympic stadium hosted the first [Bandy World Championship](/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship "Bandy World Championship") in 1957.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-194)^{#cite_ref-194}

Helsinki was elected host-city of the 1940 Summer Olympics, but due to World War II they were canceled. Instead Helsinki was the host of the 1952 Summer Olympics. The Olympics were a landmark event symbolically and economically for Helsinki and Finland as a whole that was recovering from the winter war and the continuation war fought with the Soviet Union. Helsinki was also in 1983 the first city to host the World Championships in Athletics. Helsinki also hosted the event in 2005, thus also becoming the first city to host the Championships for a second time. The [Helsinki City Marathon](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Marathon "Helsinki City Marathon") has been held in the city every year since 1981, usually in August.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-195)^ A [Formula 3000](/wiki/Formula_3000 "Formula 3000") race through the city streets was held on 25 May 1997. In 2009 Helsinki was host of the [European Figure Skating Championships](/wiki/European_Figure_Skating_Championships "European Figure Skating Championships"), and in 2017 it hosted [World Figure Skating Championships](/wiki/World_Figure_Skating_Championships "World Figure Skating Championships"). The city will host the 2021 [FIBA Under-19 Basketball World Cup](/wiki/FIBA_Under-19_Basketball_World_Cup "FIBA Under-19 Basketball World Cup"). [American football](/wiki/American_football "American football") and the [Vaahteraliiga](/wiki/Vaahteraliiga "Vaahteraliiga") has a strong tradition in the city dating back to the early 1980s.{#cite_ref-195}

Most of Helsinki's sports venues are under the responsibility of the city's sports office, such as 70 [sports halls](/wiki/Sports_hall "Sports hall") and about 350 [sports fields](/wiki/Sports_field "Sports field"). There are nine [ice rinks](/wiki/Ice_rinks "Ice rinks"), three of which are managed by the Helsinki Sports Agency (*Helsingin liikuntavirasto* ).^[\[193\]](#cite_note-196)^ In winter, there are seven artificial ice rinks. People can swim in Helsinki in 14 [swimming pools](/wiki/Swimming_pool "Swimming pool"), the largest of which is the [Mäkelänrinne Swimming Centre](/w/index.php?title=M%C3%A4kel%C3%A4nrinne_Swimming_Centre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mäkelänrinne Swimming Centre (page does not exist)") \[[fi](https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%A4kel%C3%A4nrinteen_uintikeskus "fi:Mäkelänrinteen uintikeskus")\],^[\[194\]](#cite_note-197)^ two inland swimming pools and more than 20 [beaches](/wiki/Beach "Beach"), of which [Hietaniemi Beach](/wiki/Hietaniemi_Beach "Hietaniemi Beach") is probably the most famous.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Transport")\]  

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Roads")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Helsinki_region_roads.jpg/220px-Helsinki_region_roads.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_region_roads.jpg) Helsinki region roads

The backbone of Helsinki's motorway network consists of three [semicircular](/wiki/Semicircle "Semicircle") [beltways](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road"), [Ring I](/wiki/Ring_I "Ring I"), [Ring II](/wiki/Ring_II "Ring II"), and [Ring III](/wiki/Ring_III "Ring III"), which connect expressways heading to other parts of Finland, and the western and eastern arteries of *[Länsiväylä](/wiki/L%C3%A4nsiv%C3%A4yl%C3%A4 "Länsiväylä")* and *[Itäväylä](/wiki/It%C3%A4v%C3%A4yl%C3%A4 "Itäväylä")* respectively. While variants of a *Keskustatunneli* tunnel under the city centre have been repeatedly proposed, as of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^ the plan remains on the drawing board.

Many important [Finnish highways](/wiki/Highways_in_Finland "Highways in Finland") leave Helsinki for various parts of Finland; most of them in the form of [motorways](/wiki/Motorway "Motorway"), but a few of these exceptions include *[Vihdintie](/wiki/Vihdintie "Vihdintie")*. The most significant highways are:

* [Finnish national road 1](/wiki/Finnish_national_road_1 "Finnish national road 1")/[E18](/wiki/European_route_E18 "European route E18") (to [Lohja](/wiki/Lohja "Lohja"), [Salo](/wiki/Salo,_Finland "Salo, Finland") and [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku"))
* [Finnish national road 3](/wiki/Finnish_national_road_3 "Finnish national road 3")/[E12](/wiki/European_route_E12 "European route E12") (to [Hämeenlinna](/wiki/H%C3%A4meenlinna "Hämeenlinna"), [Tampere](/wiki/Tampere "Tampere") and [Vaasa](/wiki/Vaasa "Vaasa"))
* [Finnish national road 4](/wiki/Finnish_national_road_4 "Finnish national road 4")/[E75](/wiki/European_route_E75 "European route E75") (to [Lahti](/wiki/Lahti "Lahti"), [Jyväskylä](/wiki/Jyv%C3%A4skyl%C3%A4 "Jyväskylä"), [Oulu](/wiki/Oulu "Oulu") and [Rovaniemi](/wiki/Rovaniemi "Rovaniemi"))
* [Finnish national road 7](/wiki/Finnish_national_road_7 "Finnish national road 7")/[E18](/wiki/European_route_E18 "European route E18") (to [Porvoo](/wiki/Porvoo "Porvoo") and [Kotka](/wiki/Kotka "Kotka")).

Helsinki has some 390 cars per 1000 inhabitants.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-199)^ This is less than in cities of similar population and construction density, such as Brussels' 483 per 1000, Stockholm's 401, and Oslo's 413.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-200)^^[\[198\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}  

### Intercity rail {#Intercity_rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Intercity rail")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Helsinki_Railway_Station_20050604.jpg/220px-Helsinki_Railway_Station_20050604.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_Railway_Station_20050604.jpg) [Central railway station](/wiki/Helsinki_Central_railway_station "Helsinki Central railway station"), inaugurated 1919

[Helsinki Central Railway Station](/wiki/Helsinki_Central_Railway_Station "Helsinki Central Railway Station") is the main terminus of the rail network in Finland. Two rail corridors lead out of Helsinki, the Main Line to the north (to [Tampere](/wiki/Tampere "Tampere"), [Oulu](/wiki/Oulu "Oulu"), [Rovaniemi](/wiki/Rovaniemi "Rovaniemi")), and the Coastal Line to the west (to [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku")). The [Main Line](/wiki/Finnish_Main_Line "Finnish Main Line") (*päärata* ), which is the first railway line in Finland, was officially opened on 17 March 1862, between cities of Helsinki and [Hämeenlinna](/wiki/H%C3%A4meenlinna "Hämeenlinna").^[\[199\]](#cite_note-202)^ The railway connection to the east branches from the Main Line outside of Helsinki at Kerava, and leads via [Lahti](/wiki/Lahti "Lahti") to eastern parts of Finland.{#cite_ref-202}

A majority of intercity passenger services in Finland originate or terminate at the Helsinki Central Railway Station. All major cities in Finland are connected to Helsinki by rail service, with departures several times a day. The most frequent service is to Tampere, with more than 25 intercity departures per day as of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^.

Until 2022 there also was an international services from Helsinki to Saint Petersburg and Moscow. The Saint Petersburg to Helsinki route was operated by [Allegro high-speed trains](/wiki/Allegro_(train) "Allegro (train)").

A [Helsinki to Tallinn Tunnel](/wiki/Helsinki_to_Tallinn_Tunnel "Helsinki to Tallinn Tunnel") has been proposed^[\[200\]](#cite_note-203)^ and agreed upon by representatives of the cities.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-204)^ The rail tunnel would connect Helsinki to the [Estonian](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia") capital [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn"), further linking Helsinki to the rest of continental Europe by [Rail Baltica](/wiki/Rail_Baltica "Rail Baltica").{#cite_ref-204}  

### Aviation {#Aviation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Aviation")\]

Air traffic is handled primarily from [Helsinki Airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport"), located approximately 17 kilometres (11 mi) north of Helsinki's downtown area, in the neighbouring city of [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa"). Helsinki's own airport, [Helsinki-Malmi Airport](/wiki/Helsinki-Malmi_Airport "Helsinki-Malmi Airport"), is mainly used for general and private aviation. Charter flights are available from [Hernesaari Heliport](/wiki/Hernesaari_Heliport "Hernesaari Heliport").  

### Sea transport {#Sea_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Sea transport")\]  
Main article: [Port of Helsinki](/wiki/Port_of_Helsinki "Port of Helsinki")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Helsinki_%2823883925315%29.jpg/280px-Helsinki_%2823883925315%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_(23883925315).jpg) The [South Harbour](/wiki/South_Harbour,_Helsinki "South Harbour, Helsinki")

Like many other cities, Helsinki was deliberately founded at a location on the sea in order to take advantage of shipping. The freezing of the sea imposed limitations on sea traffic up to the end of the 19th century. But for the last hundred years, the routes leading to Helsinki have been kept open even in winter with the aid of [icebreakers](/wiki/Icebreaker "Icebreaker"), many of them built in the Helsinki Hietalahti shipyard. The arrival and departure of ships has also been a part of everyday life in Helsinki. Regular route traffic from Helsinki to Stockholm, Tallinn, and Saint Petersburg began as far back as 1837. Over 300 cruise ships and 360,000 cruise passengers visit Helsinki annually. There are international cruise ship docks in [South Harbour](/wiki/South_Harbour,_Helsinki "South Harbour, Helsinki"), [Katajanokka](/wiki/Katajanokka "Katajanokka"), [West Harbour](/wiki/West_Harbour,_Helsinki "West Harbour, Helsinki"), and [Hernesaari](/wiki/Hernesaari "Hernesaari"). In terms of combined liner and cruise passengers, the [Port of Helsinki](/wiki/Port_of_Helsinki "Port of Helsinki") overtook the [Port of Dover](/wiki/Port_of_Dover "Port of Dover") in 2017 to become the [busiest passenger port in the world](/wiki/List_of_busiest_cruise_ports_by_passengers "List of busiest cruise ports by passengers").^[\[202\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}

Ferry connections to Tallinn, [Mariehamn](/wiki/Mariehamn "Mariehamn"), and Stockholm are serviced by various companies; very popular [MS *J. L. Runeberg*](/wiki/MS_J._L._Runeberg "MS J. L. Runeberg") ferry connection to Finland's second oldest city, [medieval](/wiki/Medieval "Medieval") old town of [Porvoo](/wiki/Porvoo "Porvoo"), is also available for tourists.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-206)^ [Finnlines](/wiki/Finnlines "Finnlines") passenger-freight ferries to [Gdynia](/wiki/Gdynia "Gdynia"), Poland; [Travemünde](/wiki/Travem%C3%BCnde "Travemünde"), Germany; and [Rostock](/wiki/Rostock "Rostock"), Germany are also available. [St. Peter Line](/wiki/St._Peter_Line "St. Peter Line") offers passenger ferry service to Saint Petersburg several times a week.{#cite_ref-206}  

### Urban transport {#Urban_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Urban transport")\]  
Main article: [Public transport in Helsinki](/wiki/Public_transport_in_Helsinki "Public transport in Helsinki")  
See also: [Trams in Helsinki](/wiki/Trams_in_Helsinki "Trams in Helsinki"), [Helsinki Metro](/wiki/Helsinki_Metro "Helsinki Metro"), and [Helsinki City Bikes](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Bikes "Helsinki City Bikes")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Munkkisaari_tram_stop_at_Telakkakatu_in_Eira%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2021_April.jpg/220px-Munkkisaari_tram_stop_at_Telakkakatu_in_Eira%2C_Helsinki%2C_Finland%2C_2021_April.jpg)](/wiki/File:Munkkisaari_tram_stop_at_Telakkakatu_in_Eira,_Helsinki,_Finland,_2021_April.jpg) [Helsinki tram network](/wiki/Trams_in_Helsinki "Trams in Helsinki") is one of the most dense in Europe.

In the Helsinki metropolitan area, [public transportation](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") is managed by the [Helsinki Regional Transport Authority](/wiki/Helsinki_Regional_Transport_Authority "Helsinki Regional Transport Authority"), the metropolitan area transportation authority. The diverse [public transport system](/wiki/Public_transport_in_Helsinki "Public transport in Helsinki") consists of [trams](/wiki/Helsinki_tram "Helsinki tram"), [commuter rail](/wiki/VR_commuter_rail "VR commuter rail"), the [metro](/wiki/Helsinki_Metro "Helsinki Metro"), [bus](/wiki/Bus "Bus") lines, two [ferry](/wiki/Ferry "Ferry") lines and a [public bike system](/wiki/Helsinki_City_Bikes "Helsinki City Bikes").

[Helsinki's tram system](/wiki/Trams_in_Helsinki "Trams in Helsinki") dates back to 1891 when the first [horse-drawn](/wiki/Horse-drawn "Horse-drawn") trams were introduced; the system was electrified in 1900.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-207)^ As of January 2024^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^, the system consists of 14 routes covering the inner part of the city center and [one](/wiki/Helsinki_light_rail_line_15 "Helsinki light rail line 15") newer [light rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") style line connecting [Keilaniemi](/wiki/Keilaniemi "Keilaniemi") in Espoo with [Itäkeskus](/wiki/It%C3%A4keskus "Itäkeskus") in eastern Helsinki. The length of the network is [planned to more than double](/wiki/Planned_tram_projects_in_Helsinki "Planned tram projects in Helsinki") during the 2020s and 2030s compared to 2021, with major projects including [Vantaa light rail](/wiki/Vantaa_light_rail "Vantaa light rail"), the [Crown Bridges](/wiki/Crown_Bridges "Crown Bridges") link to the island of [Laajasalo](/wiki/Laajasalo "Laajasalo") and the [West Helsinki light rail](/wiki/West_Helsinki_light_rail "West Helsinki light rail") project connecting [Kannelmäki](/wiki/Kannelm%C3%A4ki "Kannelmäki") to the city center.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-208)^ Construction work on the new tram as the number line 13 (Nihti--Kalasatama--Vallilanlaakso--Pasila) has begun in May 2020, and the line is scheduled for completion in 2024.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-209)^{#cite_ref-209}

The [commuter rail system](/wiki/Helsinki_commuter_rail "Helsinki commuter rail") includes purpose-built double track for local services in two rail corridors along intercity railways, and the [Ring Rail Line](/wiki/Ring_Rail_Line "Ring Rail Line"), an urban double-track railway with a station at the [Helsinki Airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport") in Vantaa. Electric operation of commuter trains was first begun in 1969, and the system has been gradually expanded since. 15 different services are operated as of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit)^, some extending outside of the Helsinki region. The frequent services run at a 10-minute headway in peak traffic.

### Twin towns and sister cities {#Twin_towns_and_sister_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Helsinki&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Twin towns and sister cities")\]  
See also: [List of twin towns and sister cities in Finland](/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Finland "List of twin towns and sister cities in Finland")

Helsinki has no official sister cities except [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), China. On July 14, 2006, Beijing and Helsinki officially became sister cities. In October 2019, the two cities signed the Work Plan for Promoting the Cooperation between Beijing and Helsinki (19-2023).^[\[207\]](#cite_note-210)^^[\[208\]](#cite_note-pc-211)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-212)^^[\[210\]](#cite_note-213)^ In addition, the city has a special partnership relation with:{#cite_ref-213}  
* ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Flag_of_Estonia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Estonia.svg.png) [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn")^[\[208\]](#cite_note-pc-211)^{#cite_ref-pc_211-1}
* ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png) [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm")^[\[208\]](#cite_note-pc-211)^{#cite_ref-pc_211-2}
* ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png) [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin")^[\[208\]](#cite_note-pc-211)^{#cite_ref-pc_211-3}

Until 2022, Helsinki also had an international partnership with the Russian cities of [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") and [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg"), which was suspended after [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine").^[\[211\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}
